profileText: A Senator from Michigan; born in Limerick, York County, Maine, September 28, 1804; prepared for college in Phillips Academy, Exeter, N.H., and graduated from Bowdoin College, Brunswick, Maine, in 1827; studied law; admitted to the bar and practiced in Houlton, Maine, from 1830 to 1833; moved to Monroe, Mich., in 1833 and continued the practice of law; member, State house of representatives 1835-1837; State bank commissioner 1838-1839; state auditor general 1842; appointed associate justice of the Michigan supreme court in 1842 and served until his resignation in 1845, having been elected Governor; Governor of Michigan 1846-1847; elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate in February 1847 and served from March 4, 1847, to March 3, 1853; chairman, Committee to Audit and Control the Contingent Expense (Thirtieth Congress), Committee on Public Land (Thirty-first and Thirty-second Congresses); president of the commission to settle Spanish and Mexican war claims 1853-1856; died in Ann Arbor, Mich., June 13, 1896; interment in Forest Hill Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: 1804-1896. 6 linear feet and 6 volumes. Correspondence, legal documents, speeches, and other papers concerning political and business activities, the election of 1848, the commission to adjust Spanish and Mexican land claims in California (1853-1856), law activities and work as law professor, and photographs. Finding aid.

In University of Michigan Law School law lectures, 1881-1919; Michigan Central Railroad Company records, 1837-1921; University of Michigan Board of Regents records, 1817-1982; Henry Philip Tappan papers, 1840-1881; Darius Pierce papers, 1910-1901; Charles T. Gorham papers, 1861-1899; George D. Hill papers, 1843-1866 and 1870-1876; Wilbur W. Bruckner papers, 1877-1968; Benjamin F. Graves papers, 1815-1949; Virginia Grant Barnes interview (September 19, 1963) including a reminiscence about her grandfather (1 volume); and Boyd family papers, 1761-1945. Finding aid.

1823-1897. 6 boxes; ca. 1,800 items. Correspondence, speeches, diary describing his move from Maine to Detroit in 1833, papers pertaining to cessions of Michigan lands by Indian treaties, and miscellaneous commission deeds and other papers.
Correspondence in Albertus C. Van Raalte papers.
